--- title: "Analysing data" execute: enabled: true error: true freeze: auto --- ## Previous steps {.unnumbered} ::: {.cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd data_file = 'data/data.csv' df = pd.read_csv(data_file) cleaned_df = df.drop('VOYAGEID2',axis=1).dropna(subset=['Captives arrived at 1st port']).fillna("unknown") cleaned_col_names = cleaned_df.columns cleaned_df.head(10) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=2} ```{=html}
Year of arrival at port of disembarkation Voyage ID Vessel name Voyage itinerary imputed port where began (ptdepimp) place Voyage itinerary imputed principal place of slave purchase (mjbyptimp) Voyage itinerary imputed principal port of slave disembarkation (mjslptimp) place Captives arrived at 1st port Captain's name
0 1714.0 16109 Freeke Gally Bristol unknown Kingston 283.0 Neale, Alexander
2 1714.0 16111 Jacob Bristol unknown Kingston 130.0 Nicholls, Philip
3 1714.0 16112 Jason Gally Bristol unknown Port Royal 278.0 Plummer, John
5 1714.0 16114 Mercy Gally Bristol Africa, port unspecified Barbados, place unspecified 190.0 Scott, John
6 1714.0 16115 Mermaid Gally Bristol Cape Verde Islands Kingston 72.0 Banbury, John<br/> Copinger, James
8 1714.0 16117 Peterborough Bristol Africa, port unspecified Barbados, place unspecified 200.0 Shawe, John<br/> Martin, Joseph
9 1713.0 16118 Resolution Bristol Gold Coast, port unspecified Barbados, place unspecified 255.0 Williams, Charles
10 1714.0 16119 Richard and William Bristol unknown Port Royal 55.0 Beckham, George<br/> Spring, Martin
11 1713.0 16120 Rotchdale Gally Bristol Africa, port unspecified Barbados, place unspecified 96.0 Hitchings, John
12 1714.0 16121 Tunbridge Gally Bristol Africa, port unspecified Barbados, place unspecified 200.0 Skinner, Peter
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} print("Index) Column name") for i,name in enumerate(cleaned_df.columns): print(i,")",name) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Index) Column name 0 ) Year of arrival at port of disembarkation 1 ) Voyage ID 2 ) Vessel name 3 ) Voyage itinerary imputed port where began (ptdepimp) place 4 ) Voyage itinerary imputed principal place of slave purchase (mjbyptimp) 5 ) Voyage itinerary imputed principal port of slave disembarkation (mjslptimp) place 6 ) Captives arrived at 1st port 7 ) Captain's name ``` ::: ::: # Data Analysis {.unnumbered} It is finally time to ask questions to our data. Let's start with some simple ones regaring the time span of our dataset. ::: {.cell execution_count=4} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ``` ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} arrival_year = cleaned_df.iloc[:,0] first_year = min(arrival_year) last_year = max(arrival_year) year_span = last_year-first_year print(first_year) print(last_year) print(year_span) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 1520.0 1866.0 346.0 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} arrival_year_raw = df.iloc[:,0] first_year_raw = min(arrival_year_raw) last_year_raw = max(arrival_year_raw) year_span_raw = last_year_raw-first_year_raw print(first_year_raw) print(last_year_raw) print(year_span_raw) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 1514.0 1866.0 352.0 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=7} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ``` ``` ::: ::: We can keep asking questions about numerical values. We focused on time in our last question, let's focus on the number of captives this time. ::: {.cell execution_count=8} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=8} ``` ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} n_captives = cleaned_df.iloc[:,6] tot_captives = sum(n_captives) ave_cap_per_voyage = tot_captives/len(cleaned_df) ave_cap_per_year = tot_captives/year_span print('Total n. of captives:',tot_captives) print('Average captives per voyage',round(ave_cap_per_voyage)) print('Average captives per year',round(ave_cap_per_year)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Total n. of captives: 5082756.0 Average captives per voyage 276 Average captives per year 14690 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} filtered_rows = len(df)-len(cleaned_df) tot_captives_ext = tot_captives + ave_cap_per_voyage*filtered_rows ave_cap_per_year_adj = tot_captives_ext/year_span_raw print('Extimated total n. of captives',round(tot_captives_ext)) print('Adjusted average captives per year', round(ave_cap_per_year_adj)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Extimated total n. of captives 9981894 Adjusted average captives per year 28358 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=11} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=11} ``` ``` ::: ::: So far we computed numbers, but data can be most effectively described using visualization. In our DataFrame we have information about three different locations: the place where the voyage started, the principal port of slave purchase, and the principal port of slave disembarkation. Let's have a closer look at these locations. ::: {.cell execution_count=12} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=12} ``` ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} start_port = cleaned_df.iloc[:,3] start_port_counts = start_port.value_counts() print(type(start_port_counts)) start_port_counts ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=13} ``` Voyage itinerary imputed port where began (ptdepimp) place Liverpool 3227 unknown 2005 London 1874 Bahia, place unspecified 1815 Rio de Janeiro 1464 ... Mangaratiba 1 Mediterranean coast (France) 1 Canasí 1 Santa Catarina 1 Portland 1 Name: count, Length: 176, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} import seaborn as sns import matplotlib.pyplot as plt fig, new_ax = plt.subplots(nrows=1,ncols=1,figsize=(8,8)) filter = start_port_counts > 50 x_data = start_port_counts[filter] y_data = start_port_counts.index[filter] sns.barplot(ax=new_ax,x=x_data,y=y_data) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=14} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](ch4_data_analysis_files/figure-pdf/cell-15-output-2.pdf){fig-pos='H'} ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} main_pur_port = cleaned_df.iloc[:,4] main_pur_counts = main_pur_port.value_counts() main_pur_counts ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=15} ``` Voyage itinerary imputed principal place of slave purchase (mjbyptimp) Africa, port unspecified 3177 Luanda 1447 West Central Africa and St. Helena, port unspecified 1139 Bonny 853 Gold Coast, port unspecified 787 ... Petit Mesurado 1 Eva 1 Pokesoe (Princes Town) 1 Sassandra 1 Sugary (Siekere) 1 Name: count, Length: 161, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} fig, ax = plt.subplots(1,1,figsize=(8,8)) filter = main_pur_counts > 200 sns.barplot(ax=ax,x=main_pur_counts[filter],y=main_pur_counts.index[filter]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=16} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](ch4_data_analysis_files/figure-pdf/cell-17-output-2.pdf){fig-pos='H'} ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=17} ``` {.python .cell-code} main_dis_port = cleaned_df.iloc[:,5] main_dis_counts = main_dis_port.value_counts() main_dis_counts ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=17} ``` Voyage itinerary imputed principal port of slave disembarkation (mjslptimp) place Bahia, place unspecified 1720 Rio de Janeiro 1651 Kingston 1576 Barbados, place unspecified 1524 Havana 893 ... France, place unspecified 1 Santa Marta 1 Dois Rios 1 Maceió 1 Bonny 1 Name: count, Length: 240, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=18} ``` {.python .cell-code} fig, ax = plt.subplots(1,1,figsize=(8,8)) filter = main_dis_counts > 150 sns.barplot(ax=ax,x=main_dis_counts[filter],y=main_dis_counts.index[filter]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=18} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](ch4_data_analysis_files/figure-pdf/cell-19-output-2.pdf){fig-pos='H'} ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=19} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=19} ``` ``` ::: ::: Let's try to make now a different type of visualization, a time series, i.e. a plot where we see how parameters change over time ::: {.cell execution_count=20} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=20} ``` ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=21} ``` {.python .cell-code} col_to_group = 'Year of arrival at port of disembarkation' col_to_sum = 'Captives arrived at 1st port' df_per_year = cleaned_df.groupby(col_to_group)[col_to_sum].sum() print(df_per_year.shape) df_per_year ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` (298,) ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=21} ``` Year of arrival at port of disembarkation 1520.0 44.0 1526.0 115.0 1527.0 46.0 1532.0 589.0 1534.0 354.0 ... 1862.0 11407.0 1863.0 6739.0 1864.0 3298.0 1865.0 795.0 1866.0 700.0 Name: Captives arrived at 1st port, Length: 298, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=22} ``` {.python .cell-code} fig, ax = plt.subplots(1,1,figsize=(8,8)) sns.lineplot(ax=ax,x=df_per_year.index,y=df_per_year) plt.grid() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` /opt/anaconda3/lib/python3.11/site-packages/seaborn/_oldcore.py:1119: FutureWarning: use_inf_as_na option is deprecated and will be removed in a future version. Convert inf values to NaN before operating instead. /opt/anaconda3/lib/python3.11/site-packages/seaborn/_oldcore.py:1119: FutureWarning: use_inf_as_na option is deprecated and will be removed in a future version. Convert inf values to NaN before operating instead. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](ch4_data_analysis_files/figure-pdf/cell-23-output-2.pdf){fig-pos='H'} ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=23} ``` {.python .cell-code} max_index = df_per_year.idxmax() min_index = df_per_year.idxmin() min_year = df_per_year[min_index] max_year = df_per_year[max_index] print('Min. n. of captives per year:', min_year,'on',min_index) print('Max. n. of captives per year:', max_year,'on',max_index) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Min. n. of captives per year: 2.0 on 1538.0 Max. n. of captives per year: 79472.0 on 1829.0 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=24} ``` {.python .cell-code} solution = 'The total number of captives is almost constant up to 1650, with the exception of two peaks around 1600 \ and 1622. The number increases steadily up to 1800 and decreases afterwords. The times series is not smooth, but it proceeds \ by low and high peek. The number of captives per year reaches its maximum on 1829 with almost 80 thousands slaves traded \ that year. The minimum is 2 captives on 1538.' question_box(solution=solution) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=24} ``` ``` ::: ::: Time series are very interesting to describe the trends of phenomema at different scale. Our plot ticks are separated by 50 years, this is fine to visualise trends over centuries, but we cannot see what's happening on decades. ::: {.cell execution_count=25} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=25} ``` ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=26} ``` {.python .cell-code} time_filter = (df_per_year.index > 1700) & (df_per_year.index < 1750) fig, ax = plt.subplots(1,1,figsize=(8,8)) x_data = df_per_year.index[time_filter] y_data = df_per_year[time_filter] sns.lineplot(ax=ax,x=x_data,y=y_data) plt.grid() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` /opt/anaconda3/lib/python3.11/site-packages/seaborn/_oldcore.py:1119: FutureWarning: use_inf_as_na option is deprecated and will be removed in a future version. Convert inf values to NaN before operating instead. /opt/anaconda3/lib/python3.11/site-packages/seaborn/_oldcore.py:1119: FutureWarning: use_inf_as_na option is deprecated and will be removed in a future version. Convert inf values to NaN before operating instead. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](ch4_data_analysis_files/figure-pdf/cell-27-output-2.pdf){fig-pos='H'} ::: :::
